nodes.text: The widespread use of constant elasticity of substitution (CES) functions in integrated assessment models (IAMs) produces artifacts—not real technical constraints—that drive monotonically and exponentially increasing carbon prices, thus misrepresenting the true costs and dynamics of long-term energy transitions
Prominent IAMs consistently project carbon prices that rise throughout the century to very high levels as a core model output

Applying CES, an economic production function designed for capital-labor substitution, to long-term technical factor substitution (fossil fuels replaced by renewables) is methodologically inappropriate because CES is share-preserving and imposes constant elasticity rather than a dynamically changing substitutability

Models that incorporate CES for energy transitions thereby generate policy-relevant artifacts (exponentially increasing carbon taxes, limited replacement by renewables) that can mislead decision makers and produce price-diversion, sticker shock, and technological myopia
Several mainstream IAMs and hybrid models (e.g., DICE variants, GTEM-C, MIT EPPA, GCAM, MERGE) use nested CES or CES variants to model production, energy supply, and technology bundles

A detailed stylized CES example substituting fossil energy (F) with renewable energy (R) shows: exponentially increasing R required to replace F, substitution saturating far from full replacement, carbon price small initially then increasing exponentially, and strong sensitivity to elasticity parameter

Empirical historical energy transitions follow S-curve/logistic or Gompertz diffusion patterns with dynamic, increasing ease of substitution during deployment, not the CES-implied exponentially harder substitution

Mathematical property: CES marginal rate of technical substitution (MRTS) depends on factor ratio (R/F) and elasticity parameter rho so that for positive rho and large initial shares CES requires exponentially increasing input of the substitute as substitution proceeds; elasticity sigma = 1/(1+rho)
Model outputs and the stylized example produce exponentially rising carbon price trajectories and limited renewable penetration for plausible parameterizations used in IAM literature

Policy implications: reliance on CES-driven IAM outputs leads to (a) price diversion away from physical planning and deployment targets, (b) political resignation due to perceived prohibitive costs ('sticker shock'), and (c) technology myopia favoring incumbent technologies already present in model specifications

A practical remedy within existing IAM frameworks is to implement dynamically varying elasticity of substitution calibrated to empirical S-curve diffusion behavior, which yields more realistic substitution trajectories and bounded carbon price peaks

Recommendation: move toward physics-informed, high-resolution energy models (or IAMs augmented with dynamic elasticity and empirical diffusion calibration) for long-term mitigation and energy availability analysis rather than relying on static CES formulations
